questions.text: A famous law assumes that human population is static. But human population and consequently human gene pool is never static. A medical student studying for his board exams comes across this concept while revising the genetics section. Which of the following is this principle most closely related to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Population genetics

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Gene Therapy: Introduction of a gene sequence into a cell to modify its behaviour .
  • • Option A. Gene Therapy:
  • • Introduction
  • • gene sequence
  • • cell to modify
  • • behaviour
  • • Option C. Human Genome Project: It is an international scientific research project . Primary goals are to determine the sequence of chemical base pairs that make up DNA and to identify the approximately 25,000 genes of the human genome.
  • • Option C. Human Genome Project:
  • • international scientific research project
  • • Option D. Eugenics (Sir Francis Galton): Is a social philosophy which advocates the improvement of human hereditary traits through various forms of intervention (GENETIC MANIPULATION)
  • • Option D. Eugenics (Sir Francis Galton):
  • • social philosophy
  • • advocates the improvement
  • • human hereditary traits
  • • Negative Eugenics: Is aimed at lowering fertility among the genetically disadvantaged (through abortions, Sterilizations and other methods of family planning)
  • • Negative Eugenics:
  • • lowering fertility
  • • genetically disadvantaged
  • • Positive Eugenics: Is aimed to encourage reproduction among the genetically advantaged (through financial and political stimuli, ​targeted demographic analyses, in vitro fertilization, egg transplants, gene cloning, etc)
  • • Positive Eugenics:
  • • encourage reproduction
  • • genetically advantaged

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Population genetics focuses on the study of genetic variation and the changes in allele and gene frequencies within populations over time .
  • ➤ Population genetics
  • ➤ study of genetic variation
  • ➤ changes in allele
  • ➤ gene frequencies
  • ➤ populations over time

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 922

questions.text: A geneticist is giving a presentation on recent advances in the field of genetics. During her talk, she mentions a groundbreaking Human Genome Project, which would subsequently pave the way for advances in many medical and biological fields. What was the primary intention of the project she is referring to?

options.label: C
options.text: Identify genes and sequences of base pair in DNA of human genome.

options.label: D
options.text: Introducing gene sequence into a cell to modify its behaviour.

questions.correct_answer: C. Identify genes and sequences of base pair in DNA of human genome.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Identify genes and sequences of base pair in DNA of human genome.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Development of new diagnostic techniques: While the HGP has certainly contributed to the development of new diagnostic techniques , this was not its primary intention.
  • • Option A. Development of new diagnostic techniques:
  • • HGP
  • • contributed
  • • development of new diagnostic techniques
  • • Option B. Confirming the Hardy-Weinberg law: The HGP was not aimed at confirming genetic laws such as the Hardy-Weinberg law but rather at mapping the human genome.
  • • Option B. Confirming the Hardy-Weinberg law:
  • • HGP
  • • not aimed at confirming genetic laws
  • • Option D. Introducing gene sequences into a cell to modify its behavior: This refers to gene therapy , which is a different field and was not the primary goal of the HGP.
  • • Option D. Introducing gene sequences into a cell to modify its behavior:
  • • gene therapy
  • • different field

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Human Genome Project (HGP) was an international research effort with the primary goal of mapping and understanding all the genes of the human genome .
  • ➤ Human Genome Project
  • ➤ international research
  • ➤ primary goal
  • ➤ mapping
  • ➤ genes of the human genome

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 921

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman with a history of a child with Down syndrome presents to the obstetric clinic for prenatal care. She is anxious about the health of her current pregnancy and wants to ensure that her unborn child does not have any chromosomal abnormalities. Her obstetrician discusses various prenatal diagnostic methods, including one that involves the aspiration of a small amount of amniotic fluid to check for chromosomal abnormalities. At how many weeks of gestation can this method be safely performed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 14th week of gestation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Amniocentesis : Examination of a sample of amniotic fluid makes possible the prenatal diagnosis of chromosomal anomalies and certain metabolic defects . The procedure can be used as early as 14th week of pregnancy when abortion of the affected fetus is still feasible . The diagnosis of chromosomal anomalies is made by culture and karyotyping of fetal cells from the amniotic fluid , and of metabolic defects by biochemical analysis of the fluid .
  • • Amniocentesis
  • • Examination
  • • sample of amniotic fluid
  • • prenatal diagnosis
  • • chromosomal anomalies
  • • certain metabolic defects
  • • procedure
  • • early as 14th week
  • • pregnancy
  • • abortion of the affected fetus
  • • still feasible
  • • diagnosis of chromosomal anomalies
  • • culture
  • • karyotyping
  • • fetal cells
  • • amniotic fluid
  • • metabolic defects
  • • biochemical analysis
  • • fluid
  • • Amniocentesis is called for in the following circumstances if the parents are prepared to consider abortion -
  • • Amniocentesis
  • • circumstances
  • • parents
  • • A mother aged 35 years or more (because of high risk of Down’s syndrome with advanced maternal age) Patients who have had a child with Down’s syndrome or other chromosomal anomalies . Parents who are known to have chromosomal translocation . Parents who have had a child with a metabolic defect - detectable by amniocentesis. The most common are defects of the neural tube, anencephaly, and spina bifida which can be detected by an elevation of alpha fetoprotein in the amniotic fluid. When determination of the sex is warranted , given a family history of a sex-linked genetic disease e.g., certain muscular dystrophies.
  • • A mother aged 35 years or more (because of high risk of Down’s syndrome with advanced maternal age)
  • • mother aged 35 years
  • • more
  • • Patients who have had a child with Down’s syndrome or other chromosomal anomalies .
  • • Patients
  • • child with Down’s syndrome
  • • chromosomal anomalies
  • • Parents who are known to have chromosomal translocation .
  • • Parents
  • • chromosomal translocation
  • • Parents who have had a child with a metabolic defect - detectable by amniocentesis. The most common are defects of the neural tube, anencephaly, and spina bifida which can be detected by an elevation of alpha fetoprotein in the amniotic fluid.
  • • Parents
  • • child with a metabolic defect
  • • detectable
  • • amniocentesis.
  • • most common
  • • defects of the neural tube,
  • • anencephaly,
  • • spina bifida
  • • When determination of the sex is warranted , given a family history of a sex-linked genetic disease e.g., certain muscular dystrophies.
  • • determination
  • • sex is warranted
  • • family history of a sex-linked genetic disease
  • • For the detection of neural tube defects , there is now the possibility of widespread screening by the determination of alpha-fetoprotein levels in the maternal serum . If the test is positive , it can be confirmed by amniocentesis .
  • • detection of neural tube defects
  • • possibility of widespread screening
  • • determination of alpha-fetoprotein levels
  • • maternal serum
  • • test is positive
  • • amniocentesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amniocentesis: Amniotic Fluid Test or AFT is a medical procedure used in prenatal diagnosis of genetic risk factors ; It can be performed ‘usually after the 14th week of pregnancy’ (and not before 12 weeks of POG)
  • ➤ Amniocentesis:
  • ➤ medical procedure
  • ➤ prenatal diagnosis of genetic risk factors
  • ➤ ‘usually after the 14th week of pregnancy’

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 923

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman comes to the genetic counseling clinic. Her family history reveals that her maternal uncle had a bleeding disorder that required frequent hospitalizations and blood transfusions. She recalls hearing that males in her family were affected, but not females. Concerned about the potential risks to her unborn child, she inquires about the pattern of inheritance of this disorder. How is this bleeding disorder, suspected to be haemophilia, typically transmitted?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. X linked recessive

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Recessive sex-linked traits
  • • Recessive sex-linked traits
  • • Haemophilia type A and B Duchenne type of muscular dystrophy Colour blindness G6PD Deficiency Hydrocephalus Retinitis pigmentosa Agammaglobulinemia, Bruton type.
  • • Haemophilia type A and B
  • • Duchenne type of muscular dystrophy
  • • Colour blindness
  • • G6PD Deficiency
  • • Hydrocephalus
  • • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • • Agammaglobulinemia, Bruton type.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key point is recognizing the characteristic features of X-linked recessive inheritance , where males are predominantly affected due to having only one X chromosome .
  • ➤ recognizing
  • ➤ characteristic features
  • ➤ X-linked recessive inheritance
  • ➤ males
  • ➤ affected
  • ➤ one X chromosome

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 918

questions.text: A pediatrician is consulting with a couple who have a family history of phenylketonuria (PKU). They recently had a child and are concerned about the potential for their child to develop PKU symptoms. The doctor explains that while genetic predisposition plays a role, environmental factors such as diet can influence the expression of certain genes. By ensuring that the child adheres to a diet low in phenylalanine, symptoms of PKU can be prevented. This strategy of influencing genetic expression through environmental changes is best described as what?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Euthenics

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Eugenics (Sir Francis Galton): Is a social philosophy which advocates the improvement of human hereditary traits through various forms of intervention (GENETIC MANIPULATION).
  • • Option A. Eugenics (Sir Francis Galton):
  • • social philosophy
  • • advocates
  • • improvement of human hereditary traits
  • • forms of intervention
  • • Negative Eugenics: Is aimed at lowering fertility among the genetically disadvantaged (through Abortions, family planning methods)
  • • Negative Eugenics:
  • • lowering fertility
  • • genetically disadvantaged
  • • Positive Eugenics: Is aimed to encourage reproduction among the genetically advantaged (through financial and political stimuli, targeted demographic analyses, in-vitro fertilization, egg transplants, gene cloning, etc)
  • • Positive Eugenics:
  • • aimed to encourage reproduction
  • • genetically advantaged
  • • Option C. Genetic counselling is a process in which genetic counsellors provide information and support to individuals and families who may be at risk for or affected by genetic disorders . These counsellors are typically trained in medical genetics and counselling techniques and work closely with healthcare providers to assist individuals in understanding the genetic aspects of their health and family history.
  • • Option C. Genetic counselling
  • • process in which genetic counsellors
  • • information
  • • support to individuals
  • • families
  • • affected by genetic disorders
  • • counsellors
  • • trained in medical genetics
  • • counselling techniques
  • • work closely
  • • healthcare providers
  • • Option D. Environmental sampling is a process of collecting and analysing samples from the environment to assess the presence of various substances , pollutants , microorganisms , or other factors . It is an essential practice in environmental monitoring , research , and public health , as it helps identify potential hazards, pollution sources, or changes in the environment over time. Environmental sampling can be applied in various settings, including industrial sites, natural habitats, bodies of water, air quality monitoring, and indoor environments.
  • • Option D. Environmental sampling
  • • process of collecting
  • • analysing samples
  • • environment to assess the presence
  • • various substances
  • • pollutants
  • • microorganisms
  • • other factors
  • • essential practice
  • • environmental monitoring
  • • research
  • • public health

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Euthenics refers to the improvement of human functioning and well-being by altering the environment . It emphasizes the role of environmental factors in the expression of genetic potential .
  • ➤ Euthenics
  • ➤ improvement of human functioning
  • ➤ well-being
  • ➤ altering the environment
  • ➤ emphasizes
  • ➤ role of environmental factors
  • ➤ expression of genetic potential
  • ➤ Euthenics is a pre-requisite for Eugenics . Dysgenics is a term describing the progressive evolutionary ‘weakening’ or genetic deterioration of a population of organisms relative to their environment.
  • ➤ Euthenics
  • ➤ pre-requisite for Eugenics
  • ➤ Dysgenics
  • ➤ progressive evolutionary ‘weakening’
  • ➤ genetic deterioration
  • ➤ population of organisms

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 922

questions.text: A medical student is studying genetic patterns of inheritance and their association with various diseases. She learns about polygenic inheritance, a form of inheritance where multiple genes collectively influence a phenotypic trait. This type of inheritance is distinct from single-gene disorders and often involves complex interactions between different genetic and environmental factors. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with polygenic inheritance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hypertension

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Hemophilia: This is a single-gene disorder caused by mutations in the X-linked F8 or F9 gene , following an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance.
  • • Option B. Hemophilia:
  • • single-gene disorder
  • • mutations in the X-linked F8 or F9 gene
  • • Option C. HOCM: HOCM ( Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy ) is often caused by mutations in single genes , such as the MYH7 or MYBPC3 genes , and follows a Mendelian pattern of inheritance.
  • • Option C. HOCM:
  • • )
  • • caused by mutations in single genes
  • • MYH7 or MYBPC3 genes
  • • Option D. Familial hyperlipidemia: This condition is often caused by mutations in specific genes like the LDLR gene , following a single-gene inheritance pattern.
  • • Option D. Familial hyperlipidemia:
  • • mutations in specific genes
  • • LDLR gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Polygenic inheritance involves the contribution of multiple genes in determining a particular trait or disease . Hypertension is a classic example of a condition that is influenced by polygenic inheritance . It results from the interplay of various genetic factors , each contributing a small effect , combined with environmental factors such as diet, lifestyle, and stress. The complexity of its genetic basis is contrasted with conditions like hemophilia, HOCM, and familial hyperlipidemia, which are more typically associated with single-gene inheritance patterns.
  • ➤ Polygenic inheritance
  • ➤ contribution of multiple genes
  • ➤ determining a particular trait or disease
  • ➤ Hypertension
  • ➤ classic example
  • ➤ influenced
  • ➤ polygenic inheritance
  • ➤ interplay
  • ➤ genetic factors
  • ➤ contributing a small effect

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 421

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the clinic with concerns about the possibility of inheriting a genetic condition that has affected several members of his family. Upon obtaining a detailed family history, the physician notes that affected individuals in every generation are both male and female and are often born to unaffected parents. Most of these aconditions follow an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. Which of the following conditions is NOT typically associated with autosomal dominant inheritance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Ataxia telangiectasia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Neurofibromatosis: This condition follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance . Mutations in the NF1 or NF2 genes are responsible for the different types of neurofibromatosis.
  • • Option A. Neurofibromatosis:
  • • autosomal dominant pattern
  • • inheritance
  • • Option B. Retinoblastoma: This is a cancer of the retina associated with mutations in the RB1 gene . It can be inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
  • • Option B. Retinoblastoma:
  • • cancer of the retina
  • • mutations in the RB1 gene
  • • Option D. Marfan’s syndrome: Marfan’s syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene , affecting connective tissues.
  • • Option D. Marfan’s syndrome:
  • • autosomal dominant disorder
  • • mutations in the FBN1 gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autosomal dominant traits
  • ➤ Autosomal dominant traits
  • ➤ Achondroplasia Huntington’s chorea Neurofibromatosis Polyposis coli, familial Brachydactyly Marfan’s syndrome Retinoblastoma ABO blood group system Hyperlipoproteinemia I, II, III, IV Polycystic, kidney Polydactyly Spherocytosis, hereditary
  • ➤ Achondroplasia
  • ➤ Huntington’s chorea
  • ➤ Neurofibromatosis
  • ➤ Polyposis coli, familial
  • ➤ Brachydactyly
  • ➤ Marfan’s syndrome
  • ➤ Retinoblastoma
  • ➤ ABO blood group system
  • ➤ Hyperlipoproteinemia I, II, III, IV
  • ➤ Polycystic, kidney
  • ➤ Polydactyly Spherocytosis, hereditary

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 918

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman and a 27-year-old man, both from the same small community, are planning to get married. They seek premarital counseling due to concerns about potential genetic risks for their offspring, as both of them have a family history of the same genetic disorder, although neither of them shows symptoms. The counselor recommends a specific screening process to help assess the risk to their potential offspring. What is this preventive approach called?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Prospective genetic counselling

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Mass health education: While important for general public health awareness , mass health education is not specific to assessing individual genetic risks for prospective offspring .
  • • Option A. Mass health education:
  • • general public health awareness
  • • mass health education
  • • not
  • • assessing
  • • genetic risks
  • • prospective offspring
  • • Option B. Legislation: This refers to laws and regulations , which is not relevant to the individualized assessment of genetic risk in a clinical setting.
  • • Option B. Legislation:
  • • laws and regulations
  • • Option D. Retrospective genetic counseling: Seeking genetic advice after a hereditary disorder has already occurred in the family . This is useful in diseases like Congenital anomalies, Mental retardation, Psychiatric illness, Inborn errors of metabolism, etc
  • • Option D. Retrospective genetic counseling:
  • • Seeking genetic advice
  • • hereditary disorder
  • • occurred in the family

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prospective genetic counseling: Identify heterozygous individuals for any particular defect (through screening) and explain to them the risk of having affected children , if they marry another heterozygote for the same gene . This is useful in diseases like Thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, etc
  • ➤ Prospective genetic counseling:
  • ➤ heterozygous individuals
  • ➤ particular defect
  • ➤ risk of having affected children
  • ➤ marry
  • ➤ heterozygote for the same gene

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 923

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman named Mrs. X presents to a genetic counselor. She is planning her second pregnancy. Her first child, a male, was diagnosed with Down’s syndrome. She is concerned about the likelihood of her next child having the same condition. Given her age and her previous child's diagnosis, what is the chance for her next child to also have Down's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 1 in 50

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Down’s syndrome is caused by an extra chromosome which occurs on the 21 st pair . The frequency of Down’s syndrome increases with rising maternal age but is unaffected by the age of the father . The risk for a woman of 20 years old is estimated at about 1 in 3,000 and that for a woman of 45 is 1 in 50.
  • • Down’s syndrome
  • • extra chromosome
  • • 21 st pair
  • • frequency of Down’s syndrome increases
  • • rising maternal age
  • • unaffected
  • • age of the father
  • • Amniocentesis is indicated in following circumstances -
  • • Amniocentesis
  • • indicated in following circumstances
  • • A mother aged > 35 years (high risk of Down’s Syndrome) Patients who have had a child with Down’s Syndrome or other chromosomal anomalies Parents known to have chromosomal translocation Patients who have had a child with metabolic defect When sex-determination is warranted
  • • A mother aged > 35 years (high risk of Down’s Syndrome)
  • • Patients who have had a child with Down’s Syndrome or other chromosomal anomalies
  • • Parents known to have chromosomal translocation
  • • Patients who have had a child with metabolic defect
  • • When sex-determination is warranted

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The three most common abnormalities tested through amniocentesis , are - Down’s syndrome ; Trisomy 18 and Spina bifida
  • ➤ three
  • ➤ common abnormalities tested
  • ➤ amniocentesis
  • ➤ Down’s syndrome
  • ➤ Trisomy 18
  • ➤ Spina bifida

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th ed pg. 917

questions.text: A couple presents to a genetic counseling clinic. They are first cousins and are contemplating having children but are concerned about the potential genetic risks to their offspring. The genetic counselor explains the various risks associated with consanguineous marriages. Which of the following statements made by the counselor regarding consanguineous marriages and genetic abnormalities is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Lowering of consanguineous marriage increases health of the community.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased risk of traits controlled by dominant genes.

options.label: C
options.text: There is increased tendency for premature death.

options.label: D
options.text: Child born out of consanguineous marriage has high risk of alkaptonuria compared to non-consanguineous marriage

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased risk of traits controlled by dominant genes.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Increased risk of traits controlled by dominant genes.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Lowering the rate of consanguineous marriages increases the overall health of the community : This statement is generally considered correct , as it reduces the risk of autosomal recessive genetic disorders in the population.
  • • Option A. Lowering the rate of consanguineous marriages increases the overall health of the community
  • • correct
  • • Option C. Consanguineous marriages are associated with an increased tendency for premature death in offspring: This is correct , as there is a higher risk of lethal recessive genetic disorders in consanguineous marriages.
  • • Option C. Consanguineous marriages are associated with an increased tendency for premature death in offspring:
  • • correct
  • • Option D. Children born out of consanguineous marriages have a higher risk of alkaptonuria compared to those from non-consanguineous marriages: This is true , as alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder, and the risk is higher in consanguineous marriages.
  • • Option D. Children born out of consanguineous marriages have a higher risk of alkaptonuria compared to those from non-consanguineous marriages:
  • • true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key point is understanding that consanguinity significantly increases the risk of autosomal recessive disorders , not autosomal dominant ones . This knowledge is essential in genetic counseling , especially in communities where consanguineous marriages are common , to provide accurate risk assessments and guidance for family planning.
  • ➤ consanguinity
  • ➤ increases the risk
  • ➤ autosomal recessive disorders
  • ➤ autosomal dominant ones
  • ➤ genetic counseling
  • ➤ communities
  • ➤ consanguineous marriages
  • ➤ common

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 923

questions.text: A medical student is studying various historical and contemporary aspects of genetics. During her studies, she comes across the term "eugenics" and seeks to understand its meaning and implications. Based on her research, which of the following best describes the concept of eugenics?

options.label: A
options.text: A state of being carried away by overwhelming emotion.

options.label: B
options.text: A drug related feeling of elation or euphoria.

options.label: C
options.text: The painless killing of a patient suffering from an incurable and painful disease or in an irreversible coma.

options.label: D
options.text: Study of hereditary improvement of humans by controlled selective breeding.

questions.correct_answer: D. Study of hereditary improvement of humans by controlled selective breeding.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Study of hereditary improvement of humans by controlled selective breeding

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. A state of being carried away by overwhelming emotion: Not related. This refers more to a psychological state .
  • • Option A. A state of being carried away by overwhelming emotion:
  • • more
  • • psychological state
  • • Option B. A drug-related feeling of elation or euphoria: Not related. This refers to a pharmacological effect .
  • • Option B. A drug-related feeling of elation or euphoria:
  • • pharmacological effect
  • • Option C. The painless killing of a patient suffering from an incurable and painful disease or in an irreversible coma: Not relarted. This describes euthanasia .
  • • Option C. The painless killing of a patient suffering from an incurable and painful disease or in an irreversible coma:
  • • euthanasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eugenics is a set of beliefs and practices aimed at improving the genetic quality of the human population through controlled selective breeding .
  • ➤ Eugenics
  • ➤ set of beliefs
  • ➤ practices aimed
  • ➤ improving the genetic quality
  • ➤ human population
  • ➤ selective breeding

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 922

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing her notes on genetic disorders when she encounters a section on autosomal recessive disorders. She recalls several characteristics of these disorders but is unsure about one statement she had written down. Which of the following statements is incorrect about autosomal recessive disorders?

options.label: A
options.text: Affect majority in later age group than children.

options.label: B
options.text: Majority of disorders of inborn errors of metabolism come under this group.

questions.correct_answer: A. Affect majority in later age group than children.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Affect majority in later age group than children

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. The majority of disorders of inborn errors of metabolism fall under this category: This is correct . Inborn errors of metabolism are often due to recessive genes, where both copies of a gene must be mutated for the disorder to manifest.
  • • Option B. The majority of disorders of inborn errors of metabolism fall under this category:
  • • correct
  • • Option C. Heterozygotes for the gene are not typically affected: This is also correct . In autosomal recessive disorders, heterozygotes (carriers) have one normal allele and one mutated allele and usually do not show symptoms of the disorder.
  • • Option C. Heterozygotes for the gene are not typically affected:
  • • correct
  • • Option D. Both males and females are equally affected by these disorders: This statement is accurate as autosomal disorders are not linked to sex chromosomes, thus affecting both genders equally.
  • • Option D. Both males and females are equally affected by these disorders:
  • • accurate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autosomal recessive disorder , typically manifest in childhood , involve inborn errors of metabolism , and affect carriers (heterozygotes) asymptomatically. Both males and females are equally affected . Understanding these characteristics is crucial for accurate diagnosis and genetic counseling.
  • ➤ Autosomal recessive disorder
  • ➤ childhood
  • ➤ inborn errors
  • ➤ metabolism
  • ➤ affect carriers
  • ➤ males and females
  • ➤ equally affected

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 918

questions.text: A medical student is studying population genetics and the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, a principle that describes the genetic composition of a population under certain ideal conditions. She is learning about various factors that can disrupt this equilibrium. To better understand these concepts, she is trying to identify which of the following factors is least likely to affect the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium in a population?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Random mating

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Gene outflow (gene flow): Gene flow, which involves the movement of alleles between populations , can disrupt the equilibrium by altering allele frequencies.
  • • Option A. Gene outflow (gene flow):
  • • movement of alleles between populations
  • • Option B. Mutation: Mutations introduce new alleles into a population , which can change allele frequencies and thus affect the equilibrium.
  • • Option B. Mutation:
  • • new alleles into a population
  • • Option D. Small population size: Small populations are more susceptible to genetic drift , which can cause significant fluctuations in allele frequencies, disrupting the equilibrium.
  • • Option D. Small population size:
  • • more susceptible to genetic drift

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hardy-Weinberg law assumes that human population is static . It states that “ the relative frequencies of each gene allele tend to remain constant from generation to generation in the absence of forces that change the gene frequencies .”
  • ➤ Hardy-Weinberg law
  • ➤ human population is static
  • ➤ the relative frequencies of each gene allele
  • ➤ remain constant from generation
  • ➤ generation
  • ➤ absence of forces
  • ➤ change the gene frequencies
  • ➤ There are several factors which influence/ forces the human gene pool .
  • ➤ several factors
  • ➤ influence/ forces
  • ➤ human gene pool
  • ➤ Large population size Random mating No migration No mutations No natural selection
  • ➤ Large population size
  • ➤ Random mating
  • ➤ No migration
  • ➤ No mutations
  • ➤ No natural selection

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 922

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to a genetic clinic with concerns regarding her family history of genetic disorders. She mentions that her maternal uncle and grandfather had a specific genetic disorder. She's worried about the potential implications for her future children. The genetic counselor lists out various X-linked disorders. Which of the following is NOT an X-linked disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Tay Sachs disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. G6PD deficiency: This is an X-linked disorder . It is caused by mutations in the G6PD gene on the X chromosome and affects the red blood cells , leading to conditions like hemolytic anemia.
  • • Option A. G6PD deficiency:
  • • X-linked disorder
  • • mutations in the G6PD gene
  • • X chromosome
  • • red blood cells
  • • Option B. Retinitis pigmentosa: While retinitis pigmentosa can be inherited in several patterns , including autosomal dominant , autosomal recessive , and X-linked , it does have an X-linked inheritance pattern in some cases.
  • • Option B. Retinitis pigmentosa:
  • • inherited in several patterns
  • • autosomal dominant
  • • autosomal recessive
  • • X-linked
  • • Option C. Vitamin D resistant rickets: This condition, also known as X-linked hypophosphatemia , is an X-linked disorder caused by mutations in the PHEX gene on the X chromosome.
  • • Option C. Vitamin D resistant rickets:
  • • X-linked hypophosphatemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ X-linked Recessive Traits
  • ➤ X-linked Recessive Traits
  • ➤ Haemophilia type A and B Duchenne type of muscular dystrophy Colour blindness G6PD Deficiency Hydrocephalus Retinitis pigmentosa Agammaglobulinemia, Bruton type.
  • ➤ Haemophilia type A and B
  • ➤ Duchenne type of muscular dystrophy
  • ➤ Colour blindness
  • ➤ G6PD Deficiency
  • ➤ Hydrocephalus
  • ➤ Retinitis pigmentosa
  • ➤ Agammaglobulinemia, Bruton type.
  • ➤ X-linked Dominant Traits
  • ➤ X-linked Dominant Traits
  • ➤ Vit. D resistant rickets Familial hypophosphatemia Blood group Xg
  • ➤ Vit. D resistant rickets
  • ➤ Familial hypophosphatemia
  • ➤ Blood group Xg

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th edition- page 918

questions.text: A young couple presents to a genetic counselor, concerned about the potential risks to their future children. The wife's younger sister has cystic fibrosis (CF), and after genetic testing, both the husband and wife are found to be heterozygous carriers for the CF gene. They want to understand the likelihood that their children might manifest the disease. What percentage of their offspring is likely to manifest cystic fibrosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 25%

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder . For a child to manifest the disease , they must inherit two copies of the mutated gene , one from each parent. Since both parents are heterozygous carriers (each having one normal allele and one mutated allele), the Mendelian genetics principle can be applied to determine the probabilities . There are four possible outcomes when two heterozygous carriers have a child:
  • • Cystic fibrosis
  • • autosomal recessive disorder
  • • child to manifest the disease
  • • inherit two copies
  • • mutated gene
  • • both parents
  • • heterozygous carriers
  • • Mendelian genetics principle
  • • determine the probabilities
  • • The child inherits two normal alleles (25% chance, will not have CF). The child inherits one normal allele and one mutated allele (50% chance, will be a carrier but asymptomatic). The child inherits two mutated alleles (25% chance, will manifest CF).
  • • The child inherits two normal alleles (25% chance, will not have CF).
  • • The child inherits one normal allele and one mutated allele (50% chance, will be a carrier but asymptomatic).
  • • The child inherits two mutated alleles (25% chance, will manifest CF).
  • • Therefore, there is a 25% chance that any given child of this couple will inherit cystic fibrosis .
  • • 25% chance
  • • given child of this couple
  • • inherit cystic fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Textbook of Community medicine by Rajvir Balwar, p 301

questions.text: Mr. X, a 40-year-old man, presents to a neurologist with a history of progressive motor dysfunction, characterized by involuntary jerking and writhing movements, along with mood disturbances. After a series of tests, he is diagnosed with Huntington's chorea. Genetic testing reveals that he is homozygous for the disease-causing allele. His wife, after undergoing genetic testing, is found to be a heterozygous carrier of the gene. They are concerned about the implications for their future children and seek genetic counseling. What percentage of their offspring is likely to manifest Huntington's chorea?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 100%

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Huntington's chorea is an autosomal dominant disorder , where just one copy of the mutated gene is enough to cause the disease . In this scenario, Mr. X is homozygous for the Huntington's gene , meaning he has two copies of the disease-causing allele . His wife is a heterozygous carrier, meaning she has one normal allele and one mutated allele.
  • • Huntington's chorea
  • • autosomal dominant disorder
  • • one copy
  • • mutated gene
  • • cause the disease
  • • Mr. X is homozygous
  • • Huntington's gene
  • • two copies of the disease-causing allele
  • • When a homozygous affected individual (with two disease-causing alleles) has children with a heterozygous carrier (with one disease-causing allele and one normal allele), each child will always receive one disease-causing allele from the affected parent . The children also have a 100% chance of receiving the disease-causing allele from the carrier parent , as it's the only type of allele the affected parent can pass on. Therefore, all their children will inherit at least one copy of the mutated gene, which is sufficient to cause Huntington's chorea.
  • • homozygous affected individual
  • • children
  • • heterozygous carrier
  • • child
  • • receive one disease-causing allele
  • • affected parent
  • • children
  • • 100% chance of receiving the disease-causing allele
  • • carrier parent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Textbook of Community medicine by Rajvir Balwar, p 301

questions.text: A medical student is attending a lecture on the history of genetics. The professor starts discussing the concept of improving the genetic quality of the human population by promoting certain traits. The student recalls the term associated with this concept but can't remember who coined it. Who is credited with coining the term ‘Eugenics’?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Francis Galton

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. James Watson: Known for co-discovering the structure of DNA along with Francis Crick .
  • • Option A. James Watson:
  • • co-discovering the structure of DNA
  • • Francis Crick
  • • Option B. Gregor Mendel: Known as the father of modern genetics for his work on pea plants.
  • • Option B. Gregor Mendel:
  • • father of modern genetics
  • • Option D. Wilhelm Johannsen: A Danish botanist who coined the term 'gene'.
  • • Option D. Wilhelm Johannsen:
  • • Danish botanist
  • • 'gene'.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Francis Galton's role in the history of genetics and his contribution to the concept of eugenics
  • ➤ Francis Galton's
  • ➤ history of genetics
  • ➤ concept of eugenics

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th ed p 922

questions.text: Dr. Amit, a genetic researcher, is leading a discussion with his team on the various approaches and ethical considerations in gene therapy for treating genetic disorders. To assess and enhance his team's understanding, he presents a series of statements about gene therapy and asks them to identify which statement is incorrect. Which of the following statements about gene therapy is considered inaccurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Abnormal gene can be swapped for a normal gene.

options.label: B
options.text: The degree to which a gene is turned on or off a particular gene could be altered.

options.label: C
options.text: Normal gene may be inserted into a non-specific location within the genome to replace a non-functional gene.

options.label: D
options.text: Gene delivery to somatic cell to treat disease is unethical.

questions.correct_answer: D. Gene delivery to somatic cell to treat disease is unethical.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Gene delivery to somatic cell to treat disease is unethical.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. An abnormal gene can be swapped for a normal gene: This is a correct description of one approach in gene therapy, where a faulty gene is replaced with a healthy one.
  • • Option A. An abnormal gene can be swapped for a normal gene:
  • • correct
  • • Option B. The degree to which a gene is turned on or off could be altered: Gene therapy techniques can include regulating gene expression , which is an accurate statement.
  • • Option B. The degree to which a gene is turned on or off could be altered:
  • • regulating gene expression
  • • Option C. A normal gene may be inserted into a non-specific location within the genome to replace a non-functional gene: This is correct method in gene therapy, where a functional gene is inserted to compensate for a non-functional one.
  • • Option C. A normal gene may be inserted into a non-specific location within the genome to replace a non-functional gene:
  • • correct method

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gene therapy is the introduction of a gene sequence into a cell , with the aim of modifying the cell’s behaviour in a clinically relevant fashion. It may be used in several ways like t o correct a genetic mutation (as for cystic fibrosis), to kill a cell (as for cancer); and to modify susceptibility (as for coronary artery disease).
  • ➤ Gene therapy
  • ➤ gene sequence into a cell
  • ➤ aim of modifying the cell’s behaviour
  • ➤ correct a genetic mutation
  • ➤ kill a cell
  • ➤ modify susceptibility
  • ➤ There is now almost universal agreement that gene delivery to somatic cell to treat disease is ethical, and that gene therapy should take its place alongside other forms of medical treatment.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th ed – 923.

questions.text: Dr. Mohan is speaking to a family who has recently undergone genetic testing due to a history of a specific genetic condition. The parents have the same gene mutation but exhibit different symptoms in terms of severity. The father has a milder form while the mother has a more pronounced form. Dr. Mohan wants to explain a particular concept to the family that might account for this variation. Which of the following terms best defines the variability in the manifestation of a genetic condition in individuals with the same mutation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Penetrance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Mutation: A mutation refers to a change in the DNA sequence but does not describe the variability in symptom expression.
  • • Option A. Mutation:
  • • change in the DNA sequence
  • • Option B. Genotype: Genotype refers to the genetic makeup of an individual . While both parents share the same genotype regarding the mutation, the term does not explain the variability in symptom manifestation.
  • • Option B. Genotype:
  • • genetic makeup of an individual
  • • Option D. Phenotype: Phenotype refers to the observable characteristics or traits of an individual . It is the result of genotype expression, but the term itself does not explain the variability in expression among individuals with the same genotype.
  • • Option D. Phenotype:
  • • observable characteristics
  • • traits of an individual

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Penetrance is the proportion of individuals carrying a particular variant of a gene (allele or genotype) that also express an associated trait. Mutation-normal genes may be converted into abnormal ones . Genotype refers to the total genetic constitution of an individual Phenotype to the outward expression of the genetic constitution
  • ➤ Penetrance is the proportion of individuals carrying a particular variant of a gene (allele or genotype) that also express an associated trait.
  • ➤ Penetrance
  • ➤ proportion of individuals
  • ➤ particular variant
  • ➤ gene
  • ➤ Mutation-normal genes may be converted into abnormal ones .
  • ➤ Mutation-normal genes
  • ➤ converted into abnormal ones
  • ➤ Genotype refers to the total genetic constitution of an individual
  • ➤ Genotype
  • ➤ total genetic constitution
  • ➤ Phenotype to the outward expression of the genetic constitution

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th ed – 916.
